data.title: BoneAttachment Lag
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
OS: Arch Linux 
Device: Macbook Pro late 2013

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
A node attached to a BoneAttachment lags behind the bone it is attached to when the bone is animating.  This is not desirable.

Example illustrating why this is an issue: a sword attached to an animated hand's BoneAttachment could appear outside of the hand

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Import an animated bone structure
2. Add a bone attachment
3. Attach a node to the bone attachment
4. Play the animation in game

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[BoneAttachmentBug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/160627/BoneAttachmentBug.zip)

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer blending 2d animations incorrectly
data.body:
**What happens:**
When blending two animations, the scale of one of them is assumed to be 0 (zero) even when no information about the scale is present in the animation tracks.

**What should happen:**
When blending an animation tracks with no information about scale:
        \* The scale is the same as the scale present on the other animation.
        \* Or the scale should be assumed to be (1, 1).
        \* Or no blending should be performed on the scale property. This is preferable, as the scale set on the editor by the user is preserved.

This bug may be related to #3711 

**Operating system or device:**
Linux Mint 17
Custom build commit 218bb112e59b20fd881e799754d7cc634f4a8bca

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/274954519/godot-issues/AnimationTreeBug.zip

**How to test:**
        \* The AnimationPlayer has two animations: horizontal and vertical, each one moves the IK chain in diferent directions to test the blending.
        \* The AnimationTreePlayer has a simple Blend2 node to blend the animations.
        \* Test by changing the amount slider on the Blend2 node.

**Notes:**
    \* The blending worked fine until a timeScale node was introduced in the AnimationTree. After that the scale (0, 0) was present for all nodes in all animations where no scale was set.
    \* After deleting the timeScale node the error persist, even after restarting the editor.
    \* Also note that I had to add the scale (1, 1) in the vertical animation in order to make it easier to see what is happening, otherwise the scale of every node is (0, 0) making it imposible to see what's going on

data.title: Make the texture import prompts output point to res:// by default
Fix to CPU skinning path when using GPU skinning (meshes with morphs)
data.body: This fixes and issue where when using GPU skinning, meshes still using a CPU path for skinning (meshes using morph data) would be skinned both on the CPU and GPU, resulting in the root bone offset being doubled and wasted performance. Detecting this based on the existance of morph data might not be the best universal solution, but it should at least resolve the issue for the time being until something broader can be introduced.

data.title: set_custom_mouse_cursor doesn't work with atlas textures
data.body:
Calling
`Input.set_custom_mouse_cursor( load( "res://atlasTexture.atex" ), Vector( 0, 0 ) )`
results in entire texture texture being set as cursor, not just the atlasTexture region.

data.title: Fix 'FLAG_RECEIVE_SHADOWS' flag for GeometryInstances.
data.body: Instances with this flag disabled will now result in it correctly disabling shadows from affecting it.

data.title: Fixes bug with CPU skinning path when hardware skinning is otherwise enabled.
data.body: When an object was forced to take the CPU path for skinning (because of morphs in this case), the GPU skinning would still be applied and result in wasted performance and the root bone's offset being doubled. This may not be the best universal way of solving this problem, but it should at least be sufficient for now, and I imagine a longer term goal would be broader refactoring in the rendering path anyway.

data.title: Editor keyboard shortcuts
data.body:
### What?

Hello guys, so I decided I will try to implement the editor shortcuts. I know that there's a card for that in the [Trello Roadmap board](https://trello.com/c/9eX7KPGy), which kind of makes me think that this is only for the official devs to implement. Is it? If it is, I won't waste time trying, but if it isn't (anyone can implement it), it is currently a lot of fun for me to work on Godot, so I'll do my best.
### How I plan to do it

So I have read the code on how it works in the `Project Settings / Input Map`, how the `InputMap` class works, how `DefaultInput` works, how controls currently receive keyboard events and how this is all set up in the editor. I also now understand that the input map is currently stored in `Global` and saved to engine.cfg. Now as far as I understand it, `EditorSettings` is used to store, well, editor settings.

So my plan is to refactor the existing input map to a separate control, make it work not just with `Global` but also with `EditorSettings` (to store the shortcuts there), then make controls also accept action names for shortcuts (accelerators in code) and respond to them. So this would create a new tab in the editor settings, Shortcuts, which would work the same as Input Map in project settings. Controls would also accept action names (and draw the first assigned key).

This could ease up the creation of new editor shortcuts and potentially let the user set up their own actions and assign them to various buttons and menus in the editor.
### Checklist
- [x] Refactor `ProjectSettings`'s Input Map tab into a separate class
- [x] Make it work with `Global` and `EditorSettings`
- [x] Add the shortcuts tab to editor settings
- [ ] Make controls, menus and buttons accept action name as an accelerator (shortcut)
- [ ] Make controls draw the first assigned key to action
- [ ] Test
- [ ] Profit
- [ ] ???
### The question

Should I work on this? Or let someone else handle this? For now I'll assume that my effort won't be wasted and work on this.

_Note: Don't merge this PR yet... Work in progress..._

data.title: Fix Project Settings dialog add/delete global variable
data.body:
Various bugs fixes and improvements in project settings dialog:  
- The project settings is now saved after adding or deleting a global variable.
- Fix property deletion.
- Fix property duplicate when editing, happens when the category is empty.
- After adding a property, it's category will be selected(After deleting the first category is selected)

Fixes #3857.

data.title: Automatic paths resolver.
data.body:
I wonder what you think about a kind of paths database system to allow folder reorganization without 
breaking dependencies.

The editor already displays the folder tree into the "Filesystem"dock maybe it is possible to save these informations into some location or a text file at the project's root.

This database file will be updated at every scene saving or scene running. Or simply when the Filesystem dock is updated.

To use this, a function, exposed to GDScript, must be designed to pull paths strings from the database.
This function takes the file name key as argument, and tries to returns the string who is necessary in various places where a file path is needed.

`var myScene = preload(get_file_path("my_scene.scn"))`

`extends get_file_path("base_class.gd")`

Maybe it's uglier to read, but such a function allows you to rearrange the folders, 
move the files when you want without worriying about broken dependancies. It prevents you to type
long paths in your scripts if your file system becomes huge.

If a kind C++ programmer found this useful for his needs, and if it's possible to implement with not much sweat, I guess he could helps a lot of other developers.

If an easy workaround is already  avalaible I apologize for this useless proposal.

data.title: Trimesh Static bodies generated incorrectly
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 7

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The [Create Trimesh Static Body] menu option produces incorrect collision meshes. The dae import has the most significant errors. Some of the dae shapes are visually wrong, and are offset from the actuall mesh. The obj import looks like rounding errors.

Obj import trimesh collision

**Steps to reproduce:**
_Files are in the zip._
**DAE:**
- Import and open mesh
- Click the [Create Trimesh Static Body] button on all  mesh nodes
- Add camera and point it at the pole with the sphere on top

Bugs:
- All collisions objects are on an offset. 
- The sphere shape is square shape

DAE Images
- http://imgur.com/0bFwyBU
- http://imgur.com/tixoYyL

**OBJ**
- Click the menu option Import > 3d Mesh
- Select the obj
- Select normals, unselect weld vertices.
- Look at back left or right corner. 

Bugs:
- The ground collision mesh does not extend to exactly the back edges

Obj images:
- http://imgur.com/kqkW5e0
- http://imgur.com/U1typag

I don't know if the bugs would accumulate the bigger the level is.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
_**Turn on visible collision shapes. Run the project for easier comparison**_
[trimesh collision bug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/160200/trimesh.collision.bug.zip)

data.title: Holding "Ctrl+S" will display multiple save dialog
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
OS: Ubuntu 15.10 64-bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
- _What happened:_ I opened a very simple project with just one scene added on it. When I held `Ctrl+S` to save the scene, multiple save scene dialog kept popping. Even when I released `Ctrl+S`, the multiple appearing of save dialog will not stop (it stopped at a certain time after the release). Like this:

![gifrecord_2016-03-06_122852](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3685613/13552312/59389b06-e398-11e5-8ac7-b7a5a33eb387.gif)
- _What was expected:_ I was expecting that these multiple save dialog will not be appearing. When I tried to save a scene with no changes (_the one with no `(*)` on the editor tab_), I was expecting also that a save scene dialog will not appear. I was expecting also that when I released `Ctrl+S`, the appearing of multiple save dialog will stop.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new project
2. Add a new scene with just a `Panel` node
3. Save the scene on the file system
4. Hold `Ctrl+S` for about 10 seconds (_expected here to show the multiple save dialog_)
5. Release `Ctrl+S` (_expected that multiple save dialog keeps appearing and it will stop at a certain time after the release_) 
6. Move the `panel` to make changes on the scene (_expected there will be `(*)` on the tab_)
7. Press `Ctrl+S` to save the scene
8. Press `Ctr+S` again (_expected that save scene dialog will not appear since there are no changes on the scene_)

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Inherited scene saving parent nodes in incorrect order
data.body:
I created a basic "template" level scene with the following node hierarchy:

```
Level
  -> Player
    -> Shapes
```

I then created a new scene that inherits from this template scene. When I add a new Shape to the Player/Shapes node, it appears to be added correctly in the editor. However, if I try to run the scene it throws an error (without any text) in the debugger and doesn't display the shape. Upon inspecting the tscn file, I noticed the shape's parent is set as "Shapes/Player" when it should be "Player/Shapes."

Also, if I save the scene, close it, and reopen it, the shape is gone from the scene (likely due to it not knowing where to place it).

This exact same setup works perfectly fine in an identical scene I set up that doesn't use an inherited template scene as its base.

data.title: Include libffi
data.body:
libffi is a cross-platform library which allows calling C (C++ can also be called but in many cases name mangling makes it hard) code at runtime.

Foreign function interfaces are implemented by nearly all dynamic languages (Python implements it in the ctypes module, for example).

This would allow writing wrapper plugins in GDScript directly instead of writing modules in C++, which would make it possible to both use dynamic libraries from GDScript in a cross-platform manner  (#3936) and distribute wrappers to libraries directly from the asset store (since a library like GDNet could be written in GDScript instead of C++).

Implementing libffi is extremely trivial, and it could be implemented as a module shipped with Godot by default.

data.title: "Can't copy executable file" when trying to export binary without specifying a binary name
data.body:
_Bugsquad edit:_ The issue was that the editor gives a cryptic message if one forgets to define the binary name before clicking "Export". This could be improved by either filling a binary name by default, or preventing clicking "Export" if no binary name is given.

---

**Operating system or device:**
OpenSUSE Tumbleweed.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I'm unable to get projects exported using the export templates provided.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Export a project outside of the project folder using the LinuxX11" export type.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Split classes.xml?
data.body:
Currently the `doc/base/classes.xml` is 43065 lines long and has 1.22 MB on my system. A file this long makes it harder to edit, takes a lot of memory when loaded in editor and operations of type "find and highlight all words that are the same as currently selected" take quite some time.

Wouldn't it be better to split this file into multiple? For example one per class? module?

data.title: Godot random generator is broken
data.body:
As we can see here https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/core/math/math_funcs.cpp#L88 Godot uses broken way of generating random double:

```
(double)rand() / (double)RANDOM_MAX;
```

which does not give us uniform distribution.

Bad news is that gcc/clang ( and probably MSVC ) also don't have perfect double genrators :disappointed:  ( with C++11 uniform_real_distribution )

On the upside - there are some libraries that try to give ~good pseudo-random doubles ( eg. https://github.com/art4711/random-double )
